revision.text:
{{For|Alcoholic Beverage Control stores|Alcoholic beverage control state}} [[File:An abc stores in honolulu hawaii by eekim 2012.jpg|thumb|An ABC Store in Honolulu, Hawaii]] [[Image:ABC Store Guam.jpg|thumb|An ABC Store in Tamuning, Guam]] '''ABC Stores''' is a chain of [[convenience store]]s based in [[Honolulu]] owned by MNS Ltd. The chain operates 73 stores, 57 of which are located in the state of [[Hawaii]], with the remaining locations in the [[Mariana Islands]] and [[Las Vegas]]. The company now generates more than $230 million in annual profits and employs over 1500 staff, and is described as the 37th largest company in Hawaii.<ref name=ABCExpandswithDukesLane>{{cite news|url=http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/September-2017/ABC-Stores-Ventures-into-Upscale-Dining-with-Dukes-Lane-Market-and-Eatery/|title=ABC Stores Ventures into Upscale Dining with Dukes Lane Market & Eatery|work=[[Honolulu Magazine]]|date=September 26, 2017|author=Mari Taketa}}</ref>
The company also has 7 stores operating under the Island Deli brand, with a focus on groceries and fresh foods.<ref>https://www.abcstores.com/island-deli-hawaii</ref> In 2017 they opened a restaurant and [[food hall]] known as the Dukes Lane Eatery in Waikiki.<ref name="ABCExpandswithDukesLane" />
==Products== The stores sell convenience items such as groceries, as well as tourist items and [[souvenir]]s. The chain's best-selling items are tourist-oriented products such as [[Macadamia nuts]], [[sunscreen]] and [[sunglasses]]. {{Citation needed|date=December 2010}}
==History== The chain was started by Sidney Kosasa, who opened his first store in [[Waikiki]] in 1964. The stores were originally named "Mister K." Later, in order to make the store name easier to remember, the name of the stores were changed to "ABC Stores." The last Mister K was changed to ABC in 2009.
The son of a first generation Japanese immigrant, Sidney Kosasa (or rather ‘Mr. K’- known by his ABC Stores ‘Ohana’ or family) was born in Palolo Valley, Hawaii in December 1919. His first experiences in retail began while working in his parents’ grocery store in [[Palolo, Hawaii|Palolo]].
In 1949, Mr. and Mrs. K. opened their first pharmacy/convenience store in Kaimuki, Hawaii – known later as Thrifty Drugs. As business grew, his entrepreneurial and business philosophies resulted in the opening of four locations within 10 years. While attending a business convention in Miami Beach, Florida, Mr. K noticed all the tourists near the large hotels and had a vision to build a chain of resort stores in Hawaii. The first ABC Store was opened on Kalakaua Avenue in Waikiki, Hawaii in 1964.
==Locations== The stores are now ubiquitous in the tourist-oriented Waikiki neighborhood. There are 35 store locations within a one-mile radius of Waikiki alone and consequently many of these sit in close proximity to one another. The intersection of Kalakaua and Seaside Avenue alone has four ABC Stores.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,595068073,00.html|title=Ubiquitous ABC Stores score well with Hawaiian tourists|last=Song|first=Jaymes|work=Deseret Morning News|date=2004-06-04|accessdate=2006-08-30}}</ref> Many retail analysts believe this is an attempt to block other convenience stores from entering the Waikiki market and thus prevent competition{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}.
In total, there are 37 stores on [[O'ahu]], 12 on [[Maui]], five on [[Hawaii (island)|The Big Island]] and three on [[Kauai]].
There are eight stores in [[Las Vegas]], currently the franchise's only [[Mainland United States|mainland]] location.
There are also ten stores in the [[Mariana Islands]], eight in [[Guam]] (in [[Tumon]]) and two in [[Saipan]] (in [[Garapan]]).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.abcstores.com ABC Stores of Hawaii]

'''Abu Dhabi Global Market''' (ADGM) is an international financial centre located on [[Al Maryah Island]] in the heart of the [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]'s capital city, [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref>https://www.linkedin.com/company/3535099?trk=tyah&trkInfo=idx%3A2-1-2%2CtarId%3A1425353562004%2Ctas%3Aabu+dhabi+global+mar</ref>
ADGM has three independent authorities – The Financial Services Regulator, The Registration Bureau and The Courts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adgm.com/|title=ADGM {{!}} Home|website=www.adgm.com|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
In January 2015, the Abu Dhabi Global Market announced it has renamed “Sowwah Square” as [[Abu Dhabi Global Market Square|“Abu Dhabi Global Market Square (ADGM Square)”]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abudhabicityguide.com/news/news-details.asp?newsid=18055&newstype=Local%20News|title=Abu Dhabi Global Market Announces Headquarters Building On Al Maryah Island #AbuDhabi - Abu Dhabi City Guide|website=www.abudhabicityguide.com|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
[[Al Maryah Island]] is central to the Abu Dhabi government's long-term development plans for the [[emirate]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.almaryahisland.ae/|title=Al Maryah Island {{!}} Al Maryah Island|website=www.almaryahisland.ae|language=en|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> This 114 hectare island is a financial free zone, designated the jurisdiction of Abu Dhabi Global Market and a financial free zone by Cabinet Resolution Number 15 of 2013. The island will include financial, commercial, leisure, entertainment and residential developments and facilities designed to meet Abu Dhabi’s long-term development and economic ambitions.<ref>http://www.almaryahisland.ae/en/al-maryah-island/vision</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[List of financial regulatory authorities by country]] *[[List of company registers]]
==External links== *[https://www.registration.adgm.com/ Official site]

{{Infobox person | name = Alex Algard | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1975}} | birth_place = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Co-founder of CarDomain.com (1998)
Founder of [[Whitepages (company)|Whitepages.com]] (1996)
CEO of [[Hiya (company)|Hiya]] (2016) }} '''Alex Algard''' is an Internet entrepreneur. He is the founder and former CEO of [[CarDomain]], the founder and former CEO of [[Whitepages (company)|Whitepages.com]], and the founder and current CEO of [[Hiya (company)|Hiya]]. == Early life == In 1975, Algard was born in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]].Fried, John (January 1, 2006){{cite web | url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/20060101/life-essentials.html | title=''Things I Can't Live Without: Alex Algard'' Inc.com| accessdate= Apr 26, 2017}} Note: This interview revealed that Algar is age 31 in 2006, therefore he was born in 1975. His father was Swedish and his mother was Korean.Feldman, Amy (August 23, 2016){{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amyfeldman/2016/08/03/alex-algard-risked-everything-to-turn-his-struggling-firm-whitepages-into-a-growing-tech-company/#165b97ae73d0 | title=''Alex Algard Risked Everything To Turn His Struggling Firm, Whitepages, Into A Growing Tech Company'' Forbes.com| accessdate= Apr 26, 2017}} As a teenager, Algard moved to Canada. == Education == Algard has a BA degree in Economics (1996) and a MS degree in Engineering (1998) from [[Stanford University]].{{cite news |title=White Pages Founder Alex Algard Gives Up CEO Slot There To Focus On Caller ID Spinoff |first=Amy |last=Feldman |date=September 9, 2016 |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amyfeldman/2016/09/16/whitepages-founder-alex-algard-gives-up-ceo-slot-there-to-focus-on-caller-id-spinoff-hiya/#6a3c9aa1803a }}{{cite news |title=Whitepages founder Alex Algard names Rob Eleveld new CEO |first=Kurt |last=Schlosser |date=September 16, 2016 |work=Geek Wire |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/tech-moves-whitepages-founder-alex-algard-names-rob-eleveld-new-ceo/ }}{{cite news |title=Whitepages gets new CEO as founder steps down to focus on spinout company |first=Matt |last=Day |date=September 16, 2016 |work=Seattle Times |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/technology/whitepages-gets-new-ceo-as-founder-steps-down-to-focus-on-spinout-company/ }} == Career == === CarDomain === In 1998, Algard and Simon Han co-founded CarDomain, an online community for auto enthusiasts to share information about cars.{{cite news |title=CarDomain sold to Source Interlink Media |first=Liz |last=Murtaugh Gillespie |date=September 7, 2012 |work=GeekWire |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2012/cardomain-network-sold-to-source-interlink-media/ }} From 2002 to 2006, Algard left his position as CEO of Whitepages in order to focus his attention on CarDomain. He remained CEO of CarDomain until 2012, when he sold the company to Source Interlink Media, a company that owns a number of other car-oriented publications. (Source Interlink was subsequently renamed [[TEN: The Enthusiast Network]].) === Whitepages === Algard founded Whitepages in 1996 after purchasing the domain name for $900. He began the business by developing an online database of phone numbers. The website began to generate significant revenue through advertisements, hitting $66 million a year by 2008.{{cite news |title=Founder returns to Whitepages.com |first=Brad |last=Broberg |date=September 30, 2007 |work=GeekWire |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/stories/2007/10/01/focus10.html }} In 2005, two venture capital firms invested $45 million in the company. In 2013, Algard bought out the investors for $80 million, citing a desire for the company to be free of pressure from outside investors. In 2016, he stepped down as CEO of Whitepages to run Hiya full-time.{{cite news |title=WhitePages CEO Alex Algard: Not having VCs will allow a 'cleaner' focus |first=John |last=Cook |date=October 22, 2013 |work=Geek Wire |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2013/whitepages-ceo-alex-algard-vcs-business-cleaner-focus/ }} Whitepages provides fraud screening and identity verification for businesses, as well as public record background checks and directory services for consumers. === Hiya === In April 2016, Whitepages spun out its caller ID and spam-blocking service into a separate company, Hiya, of which Algard is the CEO. The service provides consumers insight into who is behind the numbers that are calling them{{cite news |title=Whitepages spins out its caller-ID business as Hiya to take on TrueCaller |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |date=April 27, 2016 |work=TechCrunch |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/27/whitepages-hiya/ }} and also protects against unwanted spam and scam calls. In August 2016, Hiya entered into a contract with [[Samsung]] to integrate its caller ID and spam protection services into Galaxy S7 phones.{{cite news |title=Samsung Galaxy Note 7 To Ship With Hiya For Robocall, Spam Protection |first=Himanshu |last=Goenka |date=August 2, 2016 |work=International Business Times |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/samsung-galaxy-note-7-ship-hiya-robocall-spam-protection-2396826 }} That same month, the company announced the launch{{cite news |title=Hiya launches network-level caller ID and call-blocking offering |first=Colin |last=Gibbs |date=August 3, 2016 |work=Fierce Wireless |url=http://www.fiercewireless.com/wireless/hiya-launches-network-level-caller-id-and-call-blocking-offering }} of Hiya Cloud, a network based solution designed to help wireless carriers protect consumers from unwanted robocalls. Hiya also provides caller ID and call blocking services for [[AT&T]] and [[T-Mobile]] Name ID.{{cite news |title=T-Mobile to offer name ID service from Whitepages |first=Sue |last=Marek |date=October 29, 2014 |work=Fierce Wireless |url=http://www.fiercewireless.com/wireless/t-mobile-to-offer-name-id-service-from-whitepages }} == Personal life == When he was a teenager, his family moved to [[Vancouver, B.C.]] {{cite news |title=Alex Algard risked everything to turn his struggling firm Whitepages into a growing tech company |first=Amy |last=Feldman |date=August 3, 2016 |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amyfeldman/2016/08/03/alex-algard-risked-everything-to-turn-his-struggling-firm-whitepages-into-a-growing-tech-company/#20497d7573d0 }}{{cite news |title=Things I Can't Live Without: Alex Algard |first=John |last=Fried |date=January 1, 2006 |work=Inc. |url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/20060101/life-essentials.html }}{{cite news |title=A Directory of Success: WhitePages CEO Alex Algard |first=Paul |last=Kim |date=February 2, 2011 |work=International Examiner |url=http://www.iexaminer.org/2011/02/directory-success-whitepages-ceo-alex/ }} He is married. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cardomain.com/ CarDomain.com Official website] *[http://www.whitepages.com/ Whitepages.com Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Algard, Alex}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Seattle]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Stanford University School of Engineering alumni]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]]

{{Orphan|date=November 2017}} [[File:Antonio z atienza,jr.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Antonio Z. Atienza Jr., Filipino jeweler.]] '''Antonio Z. Atienza Jr.''' (born August 30, 1959) is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] [[jeweler]]. As a manufacturer, exporter, and retailer of fine jewelry products, he is the owner of Goldenas Jewelry, Inc. He is a member of the Guild of Philippine Jewelers, Inc. The Guild's mission as a national organization is to promote the transformation and growth of the Philippine jewelry industry.<ref>[http://www.guildofphilippinejewellersinc.com/directory7.htm Guild of Philippine Jewellers, Inc.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928030440/http://www.guildofphilippinejewellersinc.com/directory7.htm |date=September 28, 2007 }}</ref>
Atienza, Jr.'s Goldenas metamorphosed from Boy Atienza Jewel Art, a jewelry contracting shop, which started in 1982. With 3 employees, it has now under its employ a total of 80 craftsmen and personnel. It now sells jewelry made of gold and set with diamonds, pearls, and other semi-precious stones.<ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/about_us.htm Website of Goldenas]</ref> Atienza, Jr.'s Goldenhills Jewelry showcases his Goldenas, Inc. since 1982. Goldenhills Jewelry opened its first store on June 30, 2004 at the 2nd Floor of The Jewellery, Greenhills Shopping Center, and at present, has a total of 6 branches.<ref>http://www.goldenhillsjewelry.com/</ref> ==Awards== In December 2006, “Pakpak”, a half-necklace representing the wings of an eagle, intricately crafted by Goldenas, Inc., won the top spot of the All Precious Metals Category of the Guild of Philippine Jewellers’ Jewelry Design Competition. It received another award for the interpretation of a capiz necklace entitled, “Sensuality”, a winning design in the Chic Category of the Philippine Design Competition sponsored by the Meycauayan Jewelry Association on November 17, 2006. The Bulacan Chamber of Commerce and Industry awarded Atienza Jr. as Most Outstanding Bulacan Businessman in the Jewelry Industry on December 1, 2006.
In November 2005, Goldenas garnered two awards during the Fifth Philippine Fine Jewelry Design Competition at the Metro Comedy Bar in Quezon City. The design competition is an annual event organized by the Meycauayan Jewelry Industry Association, Inc. (MJIAI) in partnership with the Product Development and Design Center of the Philippines (Design Center).
"Eternal Love" was the top placer for the Wedding Category. Marie Liza DJ Cayana, the designer, works for Goldenas Jewelry, sponsor of the prototype. Christina Maris J. Juan of the University of Santo Tomas submitted the winning design for the Chic category with her "Down to Earth" entry. The necklace, according to Christina, is something you can take from work to play. Goldenas Jewelry also created the prototype.<ref>[http://www2.mozcom.com/~pddcp/5th%20Jewlry%20Competition.htm 5th P.I. JDC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927040932/http://www2.mozcom.com/~pddcp/5th%20Jewlry%20Competition.htm |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> Goldenas, as a Philexport member, joined the Buy Pinoy goes to San Francisco from November 15 to 20, 2005 at the Philippine Center, 447 Sutter St.<ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/index.htm Website of Goldenas]</ref><ref>[http://www.goldenasjewelry.com/news_events.htm Goldenas, Events]</ref><ref>[http://www.mapua.edu.ph/news/?newsid=216 Mapua Institute of Technology]</ref><ref>[http://www.philippinecentersf.com/news/buy_pinoy.htm Philippine Center, SF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929060240/http://www.philippinecentersf.com/news/buy_pinoy.htm |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2012, Antonio Z. Atienza Jr. (1979 Accounting) was named one of the Outstanding Alumni - Diamond Awardees of the [[University of Santo Tomas College of Commerce and Business Administration]][http://commerce.ust.edu.ph/index.php/alumni-affairs/well-known-alumni/diamond-awardee-75th-years].
==Kidnap for ransom== On March 24, 1997, Atienza Jr. was [[kidnapping|abducted]] by five armed men at Dona Mercedes [[Subdivision (land)|subdivision]], [[Barangay]] Libis, Iba, [[Meycauayan]], [[Bulacan]]. After a series of [[negotiations]] between the armed men and his wife Consolacion A. Atienza, his mother Virginia Atienza and brother Alfredo Atienza, he was released at [[Pasig City]], [[Metro Manila]] on March 27, 1997 upon payment of P 2.2 million [[ransom]] and P 1.5 million after several days. Atienza Jr. sought the assistance of [[police]] operatives (who created a special [[task force]] under Joseph Cabato, Military Intelligence Group, under PTFIC). CIG [[Chief of police|Chief]] [[superintendent (police)|superintendent]] Efren Fernandez arrested 2 suspects (at the [[Meycauayan]] [[gas]] [[Filling station|station]]): Felipe Montaos and Eduardo Soriano who pointed to Gerardo Roperez [[Pseudonym|alias]] Boy Sabater, as mastermind. The other 3 suspects were later caught: Armando Pablo @ Mando, Rudy Depas @ Rudy Bigote and Pablo Anora. In July 1997 and March 2001, [[Criminal]] cases were filed with the [[Office]] of the [[Province|Provincial]] [[Prosecutor]] of [[Bulacan]], and the case was docketed as "''People versus Armando Pablo, Rudy Depas and Roperez, et al.''" for kidnapping with ransom and robbery in band. Meanwhile, Atienza Jr., his wife Connie and all their children [[human migration|migrated]] to [[Australia]] due to the [[Psychological trauma|trauma]]. The remaining 2 other suspects were later arrested. On April 19, 2007, the [[Philippine Court of Appeals]] rendered a Decision penned by Justices Mariflor Castillo, Rodrigo Cosico and Rosemarie Carandang, affirming with modification the September 3, 2003 judgment of the [[Malolos City, Bulacan]] Court. Felipe Montaos and Eduardo Soriano were released for lack of evidence while Gerardo Roperez was acquitted and ordered released. Accused Pablo, Depas and Anora were found guilty of the crimes of kidnapping with ransom and simple robbery and meted the capital punishment of Reclusion Perpetua or life imprisonment and indeterminate penalty of 6 months as minimum to maximum of six years, respectively. They were ordered to pay Atienza Jr. P 3.7 million as actual damages.<ref>Crim. Cases Nos. 840-M-97 & 907-M-2001, September 3, 2003 9 pages Decision by Judge Basilio Gabo, in People vs. Armando Pablo @ Mando, Rudy Depas @ Rudy Bigote and Pablo Anora & Gerardo Roperez, et al., Br. 11, RTC, Malolos, Bulacan</ref><ref>CA-G.R. CR – H.C. No. 00962 “PEOPLE OF THE PHILIPPINES VS. ARMANDO PABLO, RUDY DEPAS, PABLO ANORA AND GERARDO ROPEREZ - April 19, 2007, Court of Appeals, 25-pages Judgment penned by CA Justices Mariflor Castillo, Rodrigo Cosico and Rosemarie Carandang, AFFIRMING the lower Court’s Decision with MODIFICATION. CA Reporter,</ref>
Meanwhile, Atienza, Jr.'s vast [[jewelry]] (one of the biggest in the [[Philippines]]) business flourished at his office at Saluysoy, [[Meycauayan]], [[Bulacan]]. He returned to the Philippines in 2001 to testify in the case and brought home his family from [[Australia]] after 7 years.(3-25, 1997 issue of Tempo, front page and page 2, by Rolly Carandang).<ref>[http://www.tempo.com.ph Tempo.com.ph, Dragnet bags 2 pf 7 persons in Jeweler's kidnap]</ref> ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons Category}} * [http://www.goldenhillsjewelry.com/index.php Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://www.meycauayanjewellers.com/ Meycauayan Jewelry Industry Association, Inc.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130614201101/http://philippine-jewelers.com/ Confederation of Philippine Jewelers Inc. (CPJI)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081019125839/http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20081017-166875/Jeweler-with-golden-touch-makes-waves Jeweler with golden touch makes waves] * [http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/586198/symbol-undying-love A symbol of undying love Antonio Atienza of Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/09/09/12/branded-arras-not-just-weddings Branded 'arras' not just for weddings - Goldenhills Jewelry] * [http://orangemagazinetv.com/2012/endless-treasures-some-things-really-do-last-forever/ Endless Treasures: Some Things Really Do Last Forever…] {{DEFAULTSORT:Atienza, Antonio Jr.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Filipino jewellers]] [[Category:Filipino silversmiths]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Santo Tomas alumni]]

revision.text:
{{For|other persons with a similar name|August Busch (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | caption = |birth_name = August Anheuser Busch III | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|6|16}} | birth_place = [[St. Louis, Missouri]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = World Brewing Executive | spouse = Susan Hornibrook, m. 1963, div. 1969
Virginia Lee Wiley, m. 1974 | parents =[[August A. "Gussie" Busch, Jr.]] | children = [[August A. Busch IV]], Susie Busch-Transou, Steven Busch, and Virginia "Ginny" Busch, Michael Ralph Busch 8-22-1967-8-23-1967. }} '''August Anheuser Busch III''' (born June 16, 1937) is a great-grandson of [[Anheuser-Busch]] founder [[Adolphus Busch]] and was the company's Chairman until November 30, 2006. August Busch III is informally known as "Auggie" and as "'''The Third'''" or '''"Three Sticks"''' by subordinates and employees at Anheuser-Busch. He is the father of [[August Busch IV]]. ==Early life== August Anheuser Busch III was born in St. Louis, Missouri on June 16, 1937. He attended the [[University of Arizona]], but dropped out after failing. His father then gave him an ultimatum, and he began working in an entry-level position in Anheuser Busch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/43704785/ns/business-us_business/t/fall-house-busch/|title=The fall of the House of Busch|date=2011-07-17|website=msnbc.com|access-date=2016-05-13}} ==Career== August Busch III served as President of the [[Anheuser-Busch]] Companies, Inc. (ABC) from 1974 until June 2002, and Chief Executive Officer of ABC from 1975 until June 2002. He was Chairman of the Board of Directors of ABC from 1977 to 2006. He was succeeded as the day-to-day operational head of Anheuser-Busch by Patrick Stokes. Stokes' tenure marked the first time in the history of the company that a non-Busch family member ran the day-to-day operations. Busch also conferred the chairmanship to Stokes effective December 1, 2006. He retired from their executive functions at the company on November 30, 2006. He has been a director of [[AT&T Inc.]] since October 1983. He served as a Director of [[Southwestern Bell Telephone Company]] from 1980 to 1983. The CEO of SBC/AT&T, Ed Whitacre, simultaneously served on the board of A-B. They were joined on both boards by Charlie Knight, the CEO of Emerson Electric. Whitacre also served on the board of Emerson. Busch voted to approve $115 million of pay for Whitacre in a five-year period.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/static/execpay2005/LIRT9T4.html?passListId=12&passYear=2005&passListType=Person&uniqueId=T9T4&datatype=Person|title=Edward E Whitacre Jr, CEO of SBC Communications (SBC), Earns $17.4 mil|website=www.forbes.com|access-date=2016-05-13}} Busch is Chairman of the Anheuser-Busch Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee and a member of the Corporate Development Committee and the Executive Committee. As of 2007, Busch remains a Director of [[Emerson Electric Co.]]. ==Personal== He has been married twice. His first wife, Susan, is the mother of his two older children [[August Busch IV|August Anheuser Busch IV]] and Susan Busch-Transou. His second wife, Virginia, who is a practicing attorney, is the mother of his younger two children, Steven Busch and Virginia "Ginny" Busch. Unlike his father [[Gussie Busch]], August III has been a lifelong supporter of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], and a friend, ally, and financial supporter to Senator [[John McCain]] (R-AZ) and President [[George W. Bush]]. August III's eldest son, [[August A. Busch IV]], is a strong supporter of [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] politics, just like his grandfather Gussie. All four of his children are involved in the business functions of Anheuser-Busch to varying degrees: August IV was the president and CEO of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, Inc.; Susie Busch-Transou and her husband, Tripp, own Tri-Eagle Sales, a distributorship near [[Tallahassee, Florida]]; Steven Busch was his father's executive assistant and now owns Krey Distributing Company in St. Peters, Missouri; and Ginny Busch is employed by [[Busch Entertainment Company]] (BEC), working closely with A-B's [[SeaWorld]] and [[Busch Gardens]] family theme park businesses. Both August A. Busch III and August A. Busch Jr. were inducted into the [[Junior Achievement]] U.S. Business Hall of fame in 2005. August Anheuser Busch III was responsible for the donation of Mike IV, the live Bengal Tiger mascot of [[Louisiana State University]] in 1974. Mike IV, originally Jerry, was born at [[Busch Gardens Tampa|Busch Gardens]] in [[Tampa]], [[Florida]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{AT&T}} {{Anheuser-Busch Companies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Busch, August, III}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:American drink industry businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Arizona alumni]] [[Category:Busch family|August]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from St. Louis]] [[Category:Missouri Republicans]] [[Category:American brewers]]

revision.text:
'''Basel IA''' was proposed as an intermediate between the current [[Basel I]] accord and the [[Basel II]] accord that is being implemented. Basel IA would have been more risk sensitive than Basel I but would not be as complex as the advanced approach under Basel II.
On July 20, 2007 by a deal between the various US banking regulators ([[The Federal Reserve]], the [[Office of the Comptroller of the Currency]], the [[Office of Thrift Supervision]] and the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]]) it was decided to drop the proposed Basel IA and allow Basel II Standardised in its place.
The US initially proposed that banks would need to use the advanced approach only if they were to implement Basel II. The idea of Basel IA was to enable smaller US banks to adopt a methodology that is more risk sensitive than Basel I that they are currently using for calculating capital adequacy. The Fed chairman mentioned that smaller banks who do not wish to move to Basel II Advanced or Basel IA could continue to operate under Basel I.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070823110207/http://www.federalreserve.gov/boarddocs/press/bcreg/2007/20070720/default.htm Press release] by the US Fed on the deal of 20 July 2007
*More information about Basel IA can be found in this [http://www.fdic.gov/regulations/laws/federal/2006/06proposeac73a.html FDIC site], [http://www.occ.treas.gov/ftp/bulletin/2006-50.txt OCC site].
[[Category:Capital requirement]] [[Category:Financial regulation]] [[Category:Bank regulation]]

[[File:BSicon FERRY.svg|12px|alt=Ferry transportation]] '''[[Staten Island Ferry]]''' (at [[Staten Island Ferry Whitehall Terminal|Whitehall Terminal]]) | transfer = | platforms = 1 [[side platform]]
2 [[island platform]]s (1 in use, 1 abandoned) | tracks = 2 | open_date = {{start date and age|1905|July|10|mf=yes}} | structure = Underground | passengers = 8,234,513{{NYCS const|riderref}} | pass_year = 2017 | pass_percent = -7.2 | rank = 43 | accessible = yes | next_north = {{NYCS next | station=Wall Street | line=IRT Lexington Avenue Line | service=Lexington south}} | next_south = {{NYCS next | station =Borough Hall | line=IRT Eastern Parkway Line | service=Lexington far south}}
{{NYCS next|service=Bowling|terminal=(Terminal)|time=show}}
{{NYCS next | station=South Ferry | line=IRT Lexington Avenue Line | service=none |type=loops; closed | type2=no service}} | next_north_acc = {{NYCS next | station=Fulton Street | line=IRT Lexington Avenue Line | service=Lexington south}} | next_south_acc = {{NYCS next | station=Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center | line=IRT Eastern Parkway Line | service=Lexington far south}}
{{NYCS next|service=Bowling|terminal=none|time=show}} | code = 414 | legend = {{NYCS infobox legend|allexceptnights}}{{NYCS infobox legend|alltimes}}{{NYCS infobox legend|weekdaysonly}}{{NYCS infobox legend|eveningsonly}} | embedded = {{Infobox NRHP | name = Battery Park Control House | embed = yes | nrhp_type = | image = Bowling Green station 1.jpg | caption = Station headhouse on Battery Park dates to 1905 | coordinates = {{coord|40.704106|-74.014521|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline}} | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | map_caption = Location of station in New York City | built = 1905 | architect = Heins & LaFarge | architecture = | added = May 6, 1980{{NRISref|2009a}} | governing_body = Local | mpsub = {{NRHP url|id=64000566|title=Interborough Rapid Transit Subway Control Houses TR}} | refnum = 80002669 }} }} '''Bowling Green''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]], located at [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and Battery Place (at the [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]]), in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[Manhattan]]. It is served by the '''{{NYCS|4}}''' train at all times and the '''{{NYCS|5}}''' train at all times except late nights. ==Station layout== {|table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=3 |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''G''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Street Level |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=400 valign=top|Exit/Entrance
{{NYCS Platform Layout access}} |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" rowspan=6 valign=top|'''P
Platform
level''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|{{small|[[Side platform]], doors will open on the right {{access icon}}}} |- |'''Northbound''' |← {{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[Woodlawn (IRT Jerome Avenue Line)|Woodlawn]] ([[Wall Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Wall Street]])
← {{rint|newyork|5}} toward [[Eastchester–Dyre Avenue (IRT Dyre Avenue Line)|Eastchester–Dyre Avenue]] all times except nights, or [[Nereid Avenue (IRT White Plains Road Line)|Nereid Avenue]] rush hours (Wall Street) |- |style="border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|{{small|[[Island platform]], doors will open on the left for southbound trains only {{access icon}}}} |- |'''Southbound''' |→ {{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[Crown Heights–Utica Avenue (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Crown Heights–Utica Avenue]] ([[New Lots Avenue (IRT New Lots Line)|New Lots Avenue]] late nights) ([[Borough Hall (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Borough Hall]]) →
→ {{rint|newyork|5}} toward [[Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College (IRT Nostrand Avenue Line)|Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College]] weekdays until 8:45pm (Borough Hall) →
→ {{rint|newyork|5}} termination track (late evenings and weekends) (No service: [[South Ferry loops (New York City Subway)|South Ferry loops]]) → |- |style="border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|{{small|[[Island platform]], not in service, fits 3 cars}} |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|'''''Shuttle''''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|→ No passenger service (No service: South Ferry loops) |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" valign=top|'''M''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" valign=top|Mezzanine |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" valign=top|Fare control, station agent |} {{stack|float=left|{{South Ferry (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)|color=Lexington}}}} The station has two tracks and two platforms in service: a center [[island platform]] that serves [[Brooklyn]]-bound trains, and a [[side platform]] that serves uptown trains. An abandoned and walled off island platform and track on the west side of the station were formerly used by the [[Bowling Green–South Ferry Shuttle]] to the inner platform at South Ferry. South of the station, the tracks diverge into two sets. One set (the inner tracks) enter the [[Joralemon Street Tunnel]] to travel to Brooklyn: this route is used by the '''4''' train at all times and the '''5''' train on weekdays until 8:45pm. The outer tracks continue to the closed [[South Ferry loops (New York City Subway)|South Ferry]] inner loop station, which is used by the '''5''' train when it [[short turn]]s at this station during weekends and late weekday evenings. == History == When the station opened on July 10, 1905, there was as yet no [[Interborough Rapid Transit Company|IRT]] service to Brooklyn, and all Lexington Avenue trains terminated at South Ferry, using the outer-loop platform.{{Cite web|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/07/10/101363643.pdf|title=SUBWAY TRAINS RUNNING FROM BRONX TO BATTERY; West Farms and South Ferry Stations Open at Midnight. START WITHOUT A HITCH Bowling Green Station Also Opened -- Lenox Avenue Locals Take City Hall Loop Hereafter.|access-date=2016-09-04}} After the [[Joralemon Street Tunnel]] opened in 1908, some Lexington Avenue trains continued to terminate at South Ferry, even during [[rush hour]]s, while others went to Brooklyn. This service pattern was soon found to be inadequate for the high volume of Brooklyn riders. Just three months after the Joralemon Street Tunnel opened, construction began on the third track and the western island platform at Bowling Green. Once they were completed in 1909, all rush-hour trains were sent to Brooklyn, with a two-car [[Bowling Green–South Ferry Shuttle]] train providing service to South Ferry during those times. Even after the [[IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line]] local service ({{NYCS trains|Broadway-Seventh South Ferry|bold}}) began to South Ferry in 1918, the shuttle remained in operation until it was discontinued in 1977 due to budget cuts.{{cite news |title=Transit Cuts Approved by M.T.A.; Reductions Will Begin Next Month |first=Ralph |last=Blumenthal |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1977/01/15/75261767.pdf |newspaper=New York Times |date=1977-01-15 |accessdate=2010-03-03}} The shuttle platform was renovated in 1978 along with the rest of the station. The 1978 renovation covered over the original [[Heins & LaFarge]] mosaic "tapestries" that were along the walls. The 1970s renovation also led to the construction of the eastern side platform, again due to high passenger volume on the island platform. Additional exits were requested and an underpass was built, funneling some of the traffic away from the [[headhouse]] exit at the south end. This led to the station's current configuration, with uptown trains using the side platform, and [[Brooklyn]]-bound trains using the island platform (similar to the configuration at [[Broadway Junction (BMT Canarsie Line)|Broadway Junction]] on the [[BMT Canarsie Line]]). A fence is located along the edge of the island platform, preventing northbound trains from releasing passengers onto the island platform. The [[fare control]] now consists of the restored headhouse entrance at the south end, which serves only the island platform, and various other entrances that lead to the eastern side platform and down to a large fare control area in the underpass. Two elevators make the station [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|ADA-accessible]]. One connects street level with the fare control area below the platforms and tracks with an intermediate stop at the main northbound fare control area while the other connects the Brooklyn-bound platform with the fare control area below. ==Exits== The station has three street stairs, an elevator, a set of escalators, and an original [[head house|control house]]. At the station's north end at [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]], two street stairs are located at the northwestern corner of the T-intersection of State Street and [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]]. The elevator is at the northeastern corner of said intersection. There is a glass-canopied stairs-and-escalator entrance in front of the [[Alexander Hamilton U.S. Custom House]]'s north elevation, just around the corner from two entrances to the [[Whitehall Street–South Ferry (BMT Broadway Line)|Whitehall Street–South Ferry]] station on the [[BMT Broadway Line]] (which are set into the building's eastern elevation).{{cite NYCS map|Lower Manhattan}} ==={{anchor|Control House}} Control house=== At the south end of the station is the original head house, known as the '''Bowling Green IRT Control House''' or '''Battery Park Control House''', on the west side of State Street south of Broadway. This subway entrance was designed by [[Heins & LaFarge]] and built in 1905 on the west side of State Street, across from the [[Alexander Hamilton U.S. Custom House]].{{cite web|last=Framberger|first=David J.|title=Architectural Designs For New York's First Subway|url=http://www.nycsubway.org/articles/haer-design-architectural.html|work=Survey Number HAER NY-122, pp. 365-412|publisher=National Park Service Department of the Interior Washington, DC. 20240|accessdate=26 December 2010}} It has turnstiles at street level and stairs down to the island platform. Along with its twin, the old control house for the [[72nd Street (IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line)|72nd Street]] station, this building is a reminder of the glory of [[Early history of the IRT subway|New York's first subway company]], the [[Interborough Rapid Transit Company]], predecessor to the current numbered routes. Although most of the original subway's entry points had steel and glass kiosks (for example, [[Astor Place (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Astor Place]]), important stations like this one were marked with a brick and stone control house, which were referred to as such because they helped control the passenger flow. It is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. {{stack|float=left|{{Lower Manhattan transit}}}} {{clear left}} ==Artwork== The Bowling Green station has lightboxes with rotating content. The current exhibition, since April 2015, is "Breaking Ground", featuring pictures taken by Patrick J. Cashin of [[MTA Capital Construction]] projects such as the [[7 Subway Extension]], [[Second Avenue Subway]], and [[East Side Access]]. Some of these photos can be seen on the MTA's [[Flickr]] account as well.{{cite web | url=http://www.mta.info/news/2015/04/10/new-photography-exhibit-tracks-progress-mta-capital-projects | title=New Photography Exhibit Tracks Progress of MTA Capital Projects | work=mta.info | date=10 April 2015 | accessdate=13 April 2015}} == Image gallery == File:Bowling Green IRT 002.JPG|The orange tiles on the walls date to the 1970s File:Bowling Green IRT 005.JPG|Former shuttle platform on the Brooklyn-bound side File:Bowling Green entrance vc.jpg|Entrance in Bowling Green File:Bowling Green Station Entrance in Flood Prep vc.jpg|Entrance in anticipation of [[Hurricane Sandy]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Lee Stokey. ''Subway Ceramics : A History and Iconography''. 1994. {{ISBN|978-0-9635486-1-0}} == External links == {{Commons category|Bowling Green (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)}} * {{NYCsubway ref|http://www.nycsubway.org/wiki/IRT_East_Side_Line|IRT East Side Line|Bowling Green}} * nycsubway.org — [http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/artwork_show?211 The Essence of Time Artwork by Nicole Bengiveno (2007)] * nycsubway.org — [http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/artwork_show?238 A Way To Go Artwork by Zach DeSart (2009)] * Station Reporter — [https://web.archive.org/web/20131219141200/http://www.stationreporter.net/4train.htm 4 Train] * Station Reporter — Google Maps Street View] * [https://maps.google.com/?ll=40.704172,-74.01427&spn=0.000016,0.009624&layer=c&cbll=40.704258,-74.014247&panoid=zhKLSTRl90pKwN1JZbBCcg&cbp=12,227.78,,0,-1.3&t=m&z=17 Control revision.text:
'''Certified MBA''' ('''CMBA''') was a [[professional certification]] designed as an "objective measure of a student's grasp of the [[MBA]] skill set". It was offered by the International Certification Institute.
The CMBA focused on the "10 key subject areas" comprising the MBA "[[MBA#Content|core curriculum]]" ([[Financial Accounting]], [[Management Accounting]], [[Quantitative analysis (finance)|Quantitative Analysis]], [[Microeconomics]], [[Macroeconomics]], [[Finance]], [[Marketing Management]], [[Operations Management]], [[Organizational Behavior]], and [[Business Strategy]]). The certification was a series of exams taken over several days. Each four-hour exam focused on several of the subject areas and was composed of [[multiple choice question]]s. The exams were administered by [[Prometric]].
The certification was incorporated into the [[Western Governors University]] MBA program for several years.<ref name="MBAPDF">{{cite book |title=MBA BA |publisher=Western Govenors University |url=http://www.wgu.edu/wgu/prog_guide/MBA_BA.pdf |accessdate=3 November 2018 |format=PDF}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Professional certification (Business)]] *[[Chartered Manager (disambiguation)]] *[[Certified Business Manager]] (CBM) *[[Certified Management Consultant]] *[[Certified Manager]]
==External links== *The website was [https://web.archive.org/web/20120326165400/http://www.certifiedmba.com/ www.certifiedmba.com] ([[Internet Archive|archived]], 2012-03), which as of 2/14/2013 has been taken down. *[http://www.mbacertification.com/ MBA Certification]
==References==
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20090114162539/http://www.gmac.com/Selections/fall2002/newmbacert/testing.html New MBA Certification Exams: Testing What's Been Learned, and Taught], ''Selections'' magazine, gmac.com *{{cite news |author=Del Jones |date=August 26, 2002 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/companies/management/2002-08-26-cmba_x.htm |title=Controversy awaits MBA certification exam |newspaper=USA Today}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090711162142/http://itmanagement.earthweb.com/career/article.php/2173991 'Certified' MBA Arrives Amid Controversy], Datamation.com
{{reflist}}

{{resume like|date=August 2018}} {{Orphan|date=June 2018}}
[[File:Claudia-Olsson.jpg|thumb|200px|Claudia Olsson]]
'''Claudia Olsson''' (born 27 December 1983) is a Swedish technology expert, business leader, and speaker with a background in engineering and economics.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.claudiaolsson.com|title=About|website=Claudia Olsson - Official Website|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> She is CEO and founder of Exponential AB,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.exponential.se|title=Exponential|website=exponential.se|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> founder of Stellar Capacity AB,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://swedishforprofessionals.com|title=Learn Swedish today!|website=Swedish for Professionals|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> an Associate Faculty member at Singularity University,<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://su.org/faculty-speakers/claudia-olsson/|title=Claudia Olsson - Exponential Organizations, Singularity University|website=su.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> a David Rockefeller Fellow at the Trilateral Commission,<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://trilateral.org/page/21/david-rockefeller-fellows|title=David Rockefeller Fellows – The Trilateral Commission|website=trilateral.org|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> as well as a Young Global Leader<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://widgets.weforum.org/ygl-2017/|title=Young Global Leaders class of 2017|website=widgets.weforum.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> with the World Economic Forum.
== Career == Olsson started her career as Project Manager of the [[Stockholm International Youth Science Seminar]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ungaforskare.se/siyss/|title=SIYSS - Unga Forskare|work=Unga Forskare|access-date=2017-11-13|language=sv-SE}}</ref> for the Nobel Prize Committee and the Federation of Young Scientists. She then worked for the [[Swedish Trade Council]] in Warsaw and the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council|United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC)]] in New York City. She set up and managed the policy think-tank ACCESS Health International in Singapore following her work for ACCESS in India. She then served as a Senior Advisor to the Office of Strategic Analysis at the [[Ministry for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Ministry for Foreign Affairs]] in Sweden. From 2010 to 2015, Olsson served as a board member of Project Playground{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}, a Swedish non-profit organization aiming to improve the life opportunities of children and youth in South Africa. In 2014, Olsson founded Exponential AB,<ref name=":1" /> a global education company. Exponential has among other notable missions been tasked to author the ''Sweden 2030 Future Scenario''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/580cf2e91b631b2835fc1435/t/5923fadc3e00be95583e7aec/1495530207135/Scenario2030_ClaudiaOlsson.pdf|title=För digitalisering i tiden|last=Olsson|first=Claudia|date=December 2016|website=Squarespace|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref> for the Digitalization Commission of the Government of Sweden, a report released in 2016 focusing on the digital, integrated, smart and competitive society. Olsson also co-authored the report “Blockchain-Decentralized Trust” <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://entreprenorskapsforum.se/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/NaPo_Blockchain_webb.pdf|title=Blockchain - Decentralised Trust|last=Bauman, Lindblom, & Olsson|first=David, Pontus, & Claudia|date=2016|website=entreprenorskapsforum.se|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref> for the Entrepreneurship Forum.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eng.entreprenorskapsforum.se|title=Swedish Entrepreneurship Forum|last=AB|first=Houdini Group AB & Blindspot|website=eng.entreprenorskapsforum.se|language=sv|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> Also in 2014, Olsson founded Stellar Capacity AB,<ref name=":2" /> known as ''Swedish for Professionals'', a leading education company working to help professionals integrate in the Swedish society and to learn Swedish. The company has developed its own methodology leveraging new technologies and blended learning technique and aims to prepare citizens for a more globalized world. The same year, she became an Associate Faculty member at [[Singularity University]]<ref name=":3" /> following her engagement with the university as an advisor on Global Grand Challenges in 2013. In 2016, she was appointed a European David Rockefeller Fellow<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trilateral.org/download/files/annual_meeting/2017%20Washington%20Program%2019E.pdf|title=2017 Plenary Meeting|last=Trilateral Commission|first=|date=March 24–26, 2017 |website=trilateral.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref> to the [[Trilateral Commission]]. In 2017, Olsson co-founded the executive program Decoding X at the Stockholm School of Economics. The same year, she began her engagement with the [[World Economic Forum]] in their Europe Policy Group. She also shares insights into technology and globalization through the editorial column of SvD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.svd.se/claudia-olsson-en-inblick-i-kinas-digitala-transformation|title=Claudia Olsson: Inblick i Kinas digitala förändring|work=SvD.se|access-date=2017-11-13|language=sv}}</ref>
== Education == Olsson has studied International Economics and Business at [[Stockholm School of Economics]] as well as Industrial Engineering at [[Royal Institute of Technology|KTH Royal Institute of Technology]]. She has also studied at [[INSA Lyon]], France and in Karlsruhe University,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kit.edu|title=KIT - Startseite|last=Heidelberger|first=Martin|date=2017-11-13|website=www.kit.edu|language=de-de|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Germany. In 2001, she was among the 21 students selected to attend the inaugural program of the Raoul Wallenberg Academy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://raoulwallenberg.se|title=Du kan göra skillnad - Raoul Wallenberg Academy|website=Raoul Wallenberg Academy|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> In 2009, Olsson was appointed the Energy Student of the Year<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kth.se/aktuellt/nyheter/kth-student-arets-framsta-topptalang-1.55993|title=KTH-student årets främsta topptalang {{!}} KTH|website=www.kth.se|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kth.se/sci/2.840/nyheter/kth-student-prisad-for-energiomvandling-1.38116?page=28|title=KTH-student prisad för energiomvandling {{!}} KTH|website=www.kth.se|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> in Sweden. In 2010, Olsson was the first Swedish participant<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kth.se/en/alumni/nyheter/namn-nytt-1.178476|title=Name & News {{!}} KTH|website=www.kth.se|language=en-UK|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> to attend Singularity University's Graduate Studies Program. In 2017, she was selected for the Bucerius Summer School on Global Governance<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bucerius-summer-school.de|title=Home|last=Bucerius Summer School on Global Governance|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref>
== Notability == In 2018, Olsson was appointed a member of the [http://ec.europa.eu/transparency/regexpert/index.cfm?do=groupDetail.groupDetail&groupID=3572&news=1 High Level Industrial Roundtable "Industry 2030"] at the European Commission as well as a European Young Leader (EYL40) by the [[Friends of Europe]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.friendsofeurope.org/publication/who-are-2018-european-young-leaders|title=Who are the 2018 European Young Leaders? {{!}} Friends of Europe|website=www.friendsofeurope.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref> In 2017, Olsson was appointed a [[Young Global Leaders|Young Global Leader]] by the World Economic Forum.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thelocal.se/20170320/swede-who-helps-internationals-integrate-in-sweden-named-one-of-2017s-young-global-leaders|title=Swede who helps internationals integrate in Sweden named one of 2017's 'Young Global Leaders'|date=2017-03-20|access-date=2017-11-13|language=en}}</ref> In 2016, she was appointed a European David Rockefeller Fellow at the Trilateral Commission, ranked as one of the top 99 most impactful individuals of the future by TCO,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tco.se/Aktuellt/Pressmeddelanden/2016/har-ar-framtidens-99-maktigaste/|title=Här är framtidens 99 mäktigaste|work=TCO|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> and ranked as one of Sweden’s most inspiring female engineers by Ny Teknik.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyteknik.se/karriar/ranking-sveriges-30-mest-inflytelserika-inspiratorer-6392939|title=Ranking: Sveriges 30 mest inflytelserika inspiratörer|work=Ny Teknik|access-date=2017-11-13|language=sv}}</ref> In 2015, she was ranked as one of Sweden’s Top-10 Speakers 2014 by Talarforum.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.talarforum.se|title=Talarforum AB - föreläsare, talare, utbildare, underhållare, moderator, programledare, inspiratör|last=AB|first=Talarforum i Skandinavien|website=Talarforum i Skandinavien AB|language=sv|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> In 2014, she was ranked top 10 of Sweden’s Business Talents by 4Potentials<ref name="4potentials">{{Cite news|url=http://4potentials.se/sv/talent-index-and-awards/|title=TALENT INDEX AND AWARDS - 4potentials|work=4potentials|access-date=2017-11-13|language=sv-SE}}</ref> and Svenska Dagbladet.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.svd.se|title=Sveriges kvalitetssajt för nyheter|website=SvD.se|language=sv|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> In 2012, she was selected for the Symposium for Leaders of the Next Generation by the [http://www.the-stars.ch/ Star Foundation] in Penglai, China and as a Gifted Citizen and Finalist in the Global Impact Project Competition for [[Ciudad de las Ideas (conference)|La Ciudad de las ideas]] in Mexico. In 2011, she was appointed as The Young Leader of the Year in Sweden by 4Potentials,<ref name="4potentials"/> Ledarstudion,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ledarstudion.se|title=Startsida - Ledarstudion|website=Ledarstudion|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> and SvD.<ref name=":4" /> In 2010, she was the Nova of the Year (Top Talent) in Sweden,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kth.se/en/aktuellt/nyheter/kth-student-arets-framsta-topptalang-1.55993|title=KTH student, this year’s leading top talent {{!}} KTH|website=www.kth.se|language=en-UK|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> appointed a Future Leader of Tomorrow at the St. Gallen Symposium<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.symposium.org/lot|title=Leaders of Tomorrow|date=2015-12-12|work=St. Gallen Symposium|access-date=2017-11-13|language=en}}</ref> in Switzerland, and ranked as one of Sweden's 101 Supertalents<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vildandens.com/grattis/supertalang_2010.pdf|title=Sveriges 101 Supertalanger 2010|last=Veckans Affärer|first=|date=2010|website=www-vildandens.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref> in the Business Magazine [[Veckans Affärer]].

'''Right field''' – {{convert|330|ft|m|0}} }} '''Comerica Park''' is an open-air [[baseball park|ballpark]] located in [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]] [[Detroit]]. It serves as the home of the [[Detroit Tigers]] of [[Major League Baseball]], replacing [[Tiger Stadium (Detroit)|Tiger Stadium]] in 2000. The park is [[naming rights|named]] after [[Comerica|Comerica Bank]], which was founded in Detroit and was based there when the park opened. While Comerica has since moved its headquarters to [[Dallas]], the bank still retains a large presence in the Detroit area. The stadium's seating capacity is 41,083. Downtown public transportation for the park is available via the [[Detroit People Mover]] station at [[Grand Circus Park station|Grand Circus Park]], and the [[QLine]] at the [[Montcalm Street station]]. Comerica Park sits on the original site of the [[Detroit College of Law]]. ==History== ===Construction=== Founded in 1894, the Tigers had played at the corner of Michigan and Trumbull Avenues in Detroit's [[Corktown, Detroit|Corktown]] neighborhood since 1896, when [[Bennett Park (Detroit)|Bennett Park]] opened. In 1911, new Tigers owner [[Frank Navin]] ordered the construction of a new ballpark to be built on the same site. Opening in 1912, the ballpark, which eventually became known as [[Tiger Stadium (Detroit)|Tiger Stadium]], served as the Tigers' home for the next 88 seasons. By the mid-1990s, it had become apparent that the much-beloved ballpark had become obsolete and could not be renovated any further.{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Curt|authorlink=Curt Smith (author)|title=Storied Stadiums|year=2001|publisher=Carroll & Graf|location=New York City|isbn=0-7867-1187-6}} [[Groundbreaking]] for a new ballpark to replace Tiger Stadium was held on October 29, 1997. At the time of construction, the scoreboard in left field was the largest in Major League Baseball.{{cite web|first=Jason|last=Beck|title=New scoreboard in works at Comerica Park|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120215&content_id=26706422&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb|website=MLB.com|date=February 16, 2012|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120229065113/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120215&content_id=26706422&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb|archivedate=February 29, 2012|accessdate=August 3, 2018}} In December 1998, Comerica Bank agreed to pay $66 million over 30 years for the naming rights for the new ballpark.{{cite web|title=COMERICA ALL YE FAITHFUL: TIGERS INK NAMING RIGHTS DEAL|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1998/12/22/Facilities-Venues/COMERICA-ALL-YE-FAITHFUL-TIGERS-INK-NAMING-RIGHTS-DEAL|website=SportsBusiness Daily|date=December 22, 1998|accessdate=October 6, 2017}}{{cite web|first=Bill|last=Shea|title=Comerica signs sponsorship deal for new Red Wings arena|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20160224/NEWS/160229897/comerica-signs-sponsorship-deal-for-new-red-wings-arena|website=Crain's Detroit Business|date=February 24, 2016|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} It was part of a downtown revitalization plan for the city of Detroit, which included the construction of [[Ford Field]], adjacent to the ballpark.{{cite web|first=Nichole M.|last=Christian|title=Detroit Sees Park as Star Player in Redevelopment|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/11/us/detroit-sees-park-as-star-player-in-redevelopment.html|website=The New York Times|date=April 11, 2000|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} The first game was held on April 11, 2000, against the [[Seattle Mariners]]. Upon its opening, there was some effort to try to find a nickname for the ballpark, with the abbreviation '''CoPa''' suggested by many.{{cite web|first=Terry|last=Foster|title=Terry Foster Disagrees With Fans Who Dislike Little Caesars Arena Name|url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2016/04/29/terry-foster-calls-out-fans-who-disagree-with-little-caesars-arena-name/|website=CBS Detroit|date=April 29, 2016|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} It is often referred to simply as '''Comerica'''.{{cite web|first=Lori|last=Higgins|title=Fans pray for Tigers at Easter service |url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/detroit/2015/04/05/st-johns-episcopal-church-prayer-service-detroit-tigers/25332549/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=April 5, 2015|accessdate=October 12, 2017}} ===First game=== The first game at Comerica Park was held on Tuesday, April 11, 2000 with 39,168 spectators attending, on a cold snowy afternoon. The temperature that afternoon was 36 °F.{{cite web|first=Mark|last=Torregrossa|title=Top five coldest first-pitch temperatures in Detroit Tigers Home Opening Day history|url=http://www.mlive.com/weather/index.ssf/2013/03/top_5_coldest_first-pitch_temp.html|website=MLive|date=March 31, 2013|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} The Tigers defeated the Seattle Mariners 5–2. The winning [[pitcher]], as in the [[1999 Detroit Tigers season#Final game at Tiger Stadium|final game at Tiger Stadium]], was [[Brian Moehler]]. ==Features== [[File:Comerica-Park-Detroit-MI-Panorama.jpg|thumb|350px|Comerica Park panorama.]] The main entrance to the ballpark is located across the street from the [[Fox Theatre (Detroit)|Fox Theatre]] and between two historic downtown churches, [[St. John's Episcopal Church (Detroit, Michigan)|St. John Episcopal Church]] and [[Central United Methodist Church (Detroit)|Central United Methodist Church]].{{cite web|title=Getting to Comerica Park - Directions to the Park |url=http://detroit.tigers.mlb.com/det/ballpark/areainfo/index.jsp?content=directions|website=Tigers.com|accessdate=October 12, 2017}}{{cite web|first=Niraj|last=Warikoo|title=Metro Detroit churches, synagogues become sanctuaries for immigrants |url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/2017/03/13/churches-synagogues-sanctuaries-undocumented-immigrants/98865826/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=March 13, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017}} Outside of the main entrance is a tiger statue that's {{convert|15|ft|m}} in height.{{cite web|title=Comerica Park's "big tiger" to remove Carhartt jacket Friday at 6:30 a.m.|url=http://detroit.tigers.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20110407&content_id=17489278&vkey=pr_det&fext=.jsp&c_id=det|website=Tigers.com|date=April 7, 2011|accessdate=October 9, 2017}} There are 8 other heroic-sized tiger statues throughout the park, including two prowling on top of the scoreboard in left field. These tigers' eyes light up after a Tigers home run or a victory and the sound of a growling tiger plays as well.{{cite web|first=Sean|last=Rinehart|title=Detroit Tigers: 10 Things You May Not Know About Comerica Park|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1012998-detroit-tigers-10-things-you-may-not-know-about-comerica-park|website=Bleacher Report|date=January 10, 2012|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} The tigers were originally created by sculptor Michael Keropian and fabricated by ShowMotion Inc. in Norwalk, Connecticut.{{cite web|first=Bill|last=Shea|title=Detroit Tigers installing scoreboard — 4th largest in baseball — at Comerica Park|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20120216/FREE/120219906/detroit-tigers-installing-scoreboard-4th-largest-in-baseball-at|website=Crain's Detroit Business|date=February 16, 2012|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Keropian Bronze Sculpture / Tiger Sculptures at Comerica Park|url=http://www.keropiansculpture.com/north_gate_tigers.html|website=Keropian Bronze Sculpture|accessdate=October 10, 2017}} Along the brick walls outside of the park are 33 tiger heads with lighted baseballs in their mouths. At the left-center field concourse there are statues of all of the players whose numbers have been retired by the Tigers (with the exception of [[Jackie Robinson]], whose number was retired in every MLB park in 1997 and is located on the wall in right-center field).{{cite web|title=Tigers Retired Numbers|url=http://detroit.tigers.mlb.com/det/history/retired_numbers.jsp|website=Tigers.com|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} A statue of [[Ty Cobb]] is also there, but he does not have a number, as he played baseball before players began to wear numbers on their uniforms. These players' names, along with the names of [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Fame]] players and broadcasters who spent a significant part of their career with the Tigers, are also on a wall in right-center field. [[Ernie Harwell]], the team's long time radio announcer and a recipient of the Hall of Fame's [[Ford C. Frick Award]], has a statue just inside the stadium on the first base side.{{cite web|first=Ken|last=Schlapp|title=Ken Schlapp's Field Trip of Dreams - Comerica Park|url=http://www.ballparksofbaseball.com/kenschlapp/comerica.htm|website=Ballparks of Baseball|date=July 26, 2003|accessdate=October 6, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Stadium Series: Detroit's Comerica Park |url=https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/stadium-series-detroits-comerica-park/|website=CBS Sports|date=July 29, 2014|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} The field itself features a distinctive dirt strip between home plate and the pitcher's mound. This strip, sometimes known as the "keyhole", was common in early ballparks, but it's very rare in modern facilities (the only other current major league park to feature one is [[Chase Field]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]). Additionally, the home plate area is in the shape of the home plate itself, and not as a standard circle.{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Lukas|title=Some Thoughts About Infield Design|url=https://uni-watch.com/2015/09/03/some-thoughts-about-infield-design/|website=Uni Watch|date=September 3, 2015|accessdate=October 12, 2017}} In the northeastern corner of the stadium behind the stands from the third base line is a Ferris wheel with twelve cars designed like baseballs. In the northwestern corner of the stadium behind the stands from the first base line is a carousel.{{cite web|first=Tim|last=Newcomb|title=Ballpark Quirks: Comerica Park's carnival atmosphere with a view|url=https://www.si.com/mlb/strike-zone/2014/06/06/ballpark-quirks-comerica-park-detroit-tigers|website=SI.com|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=August 3, 2018}} The flagpole located between center and left fields was originally in play, as was the flagpole in Tiger Stadium. However, the left field wall was moved in front of the pole before the 2003 season. A ball that hits the pole is now ruled a home run. The right field of the stadium features the [[Pepsi]] Porch, a picnic deck between the 100 and 200 level seating bowls. Also in right field, and part of the 100 level seating bowl, is an area of seats known as "Kaline's Corner", an homage to Hall of Fame right fielder Al Kaline, who once played for the Tigers when the team played in Tiger Stadium.{{cite web|title=History of Kaline's Corner|url=https://www.kalinescorner.com/history-of-kalines-corner.html|website=Kaline's Corner|accessdate=June 4, 2018}} An [[LED]] scoreboard was added to the right-center field wall, and the upper deck [[Fascia (architecture)|fascia]] for the [[2007 Major League Baseball season|2007 season]]. [[File:Detroit 3 Automakers Homerun Fountain at Comerica Park 2009.JPG|thumb|200px|The center field fountain, now known as the [[Chevrolet]] Fountain, was originally called the [[General Motors]] Fountain. This picture was taken in 2009, when the Tigers added the logos for [[Chrysler LLC|Chrysler]] and [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] as a show of support for the struggling automotive industry. Directly behind the fountain is the [[Detroit Athletic Club]].]] A giant fountain is located behind center field. [[General Motors]] sponsored the fountain from 2000 to 2008, and used the area to showcase GM manufactured vehicles as well. While GM dropped its sponsorship for the 2009 season due to [[General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization|financial issues]], the GM branding was not removed from the fountain. Instead, signs for [[Chrysler]] and [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] were also added to the display, along with the message "The Detroit Tigers support our automakers."{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Klayman|title=Tigers give free signs to struggling U.S. automakers|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/retire-us-baseball-automakers/tigers-give-free-signs-to-struggling-u-s-automakers-idUSTRE53E73V20090415|website=Reuters|date=April 15, 2009|accessdate=June 4, 2018}} In 2010, GM returned to sponsoring the display, now known as the [[Chevrolet]] Fountain.{{cite web|first=Bill|last=Shea|title=GM renews sponsorship of Comerica Park's outfield fountain|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20100412/FREE/100419980/gm-renews-sponsorship-of-comerica-parks-outfield-fountain|website=Crain's Detroit Business|date=April 12, 2010|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} A completely redesigned and upgraded left field video display debuted for the [[2012 Major League Baseball season|2012 season]]. The serif "TIGERS" letters were removed, replaced by cursive lettering that can also display graphics and video. An analog clock below the Tigers letters and above the Comerica Park lettering was removed completely. A high-definition LED display was installed, which was much larger than the three displays that had existed there previously. The previous scoreboard utilized light bulbs - still a popular scoreboard technology around the time the park opened, though they were quickly aging as LED displays became available and were installed around other [[List of Major League Baseball stadiums|Major League ballparks]]. The scoreboard was also raised 16 feet in an effort to address complaints that the scoreboard was too far left and thus obstructed by the left field upper deck. Along with the replacement scoreboard, all remaining bulb fascia scoreboards were also upgraded to LED. In 2014, the Tigers announced a $4 million renovation to Comerica Park's Pepsi Porch. This renovation included the removal of the bleachers that once occupied this space and the addition of new stadium seats. The plan also included new high top tables, a new bar in the middle of the porch, couches and lounge chairs, as well as a fire pit. The bleachers that once occupied this area was moved to the space above The Jungle restaurant and bar. There is a fireworks show after Friday evening games usually starting after Memorial Day.{{cite web|title=Comerica Park Information - Ballpark A-to-Z Guide|url=http://detroit.tigers.mlb.com/det/ballpark/information/index.jsp?content=guide|website=Tigers.com|accessdate=October 9, 2017}} ==Dimensions== [[File:Tiled tigers logo.JPG|thumb|left|Tiled Tigers logo outside of the front entrance.]] In contrast to Tiger Stadium, which had long been considered one of the most hitter-friendly parks in baseball, Comerica Park is considered to be extremely friendly to pitchers. Except for dead center field—420 feet (128 m) versus Tiger Stadium's 440 feet (134 m)—the outfield dimensions were more expansive than those at Tiger Stadium. This led to complaints from players and fans alike. Most famously, [[Bobby Higginson]] sarcastically referred to the venue as "Comerica National Park".{{cite web|first=John|last=Romano|title=Williams goes deep for dramatic catch|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/041600/news_pf/Sports/Williams_goes_deep_fo.shtml|website=St. Petersburg Times|date=April 16, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010221080703/http://www.sptimes.com/News/041600/news_pf/Sports/Williams_goes_deep_fo.shtml|archivedate=February 21, 2001|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} Before the start of the [[2003 Major League Baseball season|2003 MLB season]], the club moved the distance from left-center field from {{convert|395|to|370|ft|m}}. This also removed the flagpole from the field of play, originally incorporated as an homage to Tiger Stadium. Two years later, the [[bullpen]]s were moved from right field to an empty area in left field created when the fence was moved in. In place of the old bullpens in right field, about 950 seats were added.{{cite web|first=Jason|last=Beck|title=Comerica Park to see alterations|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/print.jsp?ymd=20050114&content_id=931277&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb&fext=.jsp|website=MLB.com|date=January 14, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012044411/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/print.jsp?ymd=20050114&content_id=931277&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb&fext=.jsp|archivedate=October 12, 2017|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} This made one of the most pitcher-friendly ballparks transform into the third most batter-friendly (with extra bases also taken into account).[http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2022901-ranking-mlbs-most-hitter-friendly-ballparks-by-the-numbers/page/15 Bleacher Report - Ranking MLB's Most Hitter-Friendly Ballparks, by the Numbers - 3. Comerica Park] Also of note, the current layout of the playing field at Comerica Park means that when a player is at bat, the direction he is facing looks farther to the south than at any other Major League Baseball park.{{cite web|last=Robinson|first=Craig|title=Ballpark Orientation: Direction the Batter is Facing at all MLB Parks|work=Flip Flop Fly Ball|publisher=Bloomsbury|url=http://www.flipflopflyin.com/flipflopflyball/info-orientation.html}} ==Stadium use== [[File:Comericapano.jpg|thumb|350px|Downtown Detroit skyline as seen from upper deck.]] ===Baseball=== In [[2005 in baseball|2005]], Comerica Park hosted the [[2005 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|76th MLB All-Star Game]], the first to be played in Detroit since 1971. In the [[Home Run Derby (Major League Baseball)|Home Run Derby]], held the day before, [[Bobby Abreu]] slammed 24 home runs in the first round, breaking the previous record of 15. Abreu won the Derby over Tiger [[Iván Rodríguez]], hitting a then record 41 homers during the event.{{cite web|title=Abreu shatters Home Run Derby records|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/allstar05/news/story?id=2105813|website=ESPN.com|date=July 12, 2005|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} In the All-Star Game, the American League won 7–5 with [[Miguel Tejada]] winning the game's [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game Most Valuable Player Award|MVP Award]].{{cite web|title=Tejada homers, named All-Star MVP|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/allstar05/news/story?id=2106569|website=ESPN.com|date=July 13, 2005|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} The first playoff game at Comerica Park was played on October 6, 2006 against the [[New York Yankees]].{{cite web|title=2006 American League Division Series (ALDS) Game 3, Yankees at Tigers, October 6|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET200610060.shtml|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=October 8, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Gambler outduels Unit; Tigers take 2-1 lead vs. Yanks|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/recap?gameId=261006106|website=ESPN.com|date=October 7, 2006|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} On October 21, 2006, Comerica Park hosted the first [[World Series]] game in the history of the ballpark (Game 1 of the [[2006 World Series]]).{{cite web|title=2006 World Series Game 1, Cardinals at Tigers, October 21|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET200610210.shtml|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=October 13, 2017}} On June 12, 2007, the first [[no-hitter]] was thrown at Comerica Park by [[Justin Verlander]]. The Tigers won the game 4–0 against the [[2007 Milwaukee Brewers season|Milwaukee Brewers]]. It was also the first no-hitter thrown by a Tiger in the city of Detroit since [[Virgil Trucks]] accomplished the feat in 1952.{{cite web|first=Christoper D|last=Thomas|title=Justin Verlander's best moments with the Detroit Tigers|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/mlb/tigers/2017/09/01/detroit-tigers-justin-verlander-top-moments/623941001/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=September 1, 2017|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} On May 24, 2008, the Tiger statue at the main entrance to the ballpark was dressed with a [[Detroit Red Wings]] jersey as the Red Wings were playing against the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] in the [[2008 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup Finals]] during that time. Detroit defeated Pittsburgh in 6 games for the [[Stanley Cup]]. The jersey is usually worn by the [[Spirit of Detroit]], but it was undergoing restoration during that time.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/05-23-2008/0004820191&EDATE=|title=Hockeytown Mania in Detroit as Red Wings Battle for the Stanley Cup|first=Detroit Red|last=Wings|date=|website=www.prnewswire.com|accessdate=17 March 2018}} On August 15, 2011, [[Minnesota Twins]] slugger [[Jim Thome]] became the 8th player in baseball history to hit 600 career home runs.{{cite web|title=Jim Thome hits 600th home run|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/6864854/minnesota-twins-slugger-jim-thome-clubs-600th-career-homer|website=ESPN.com|date=August 15, 2011|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} Comerica Park hosted its second World Series in [[2012 World Series|2012]], with the Tigers getting swept by the [[2012 San Francisco Giants season|San Francisco Giants]].{{cite web|title=2012 World Series Game 3, Giants at Tigers, October 27|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET201210270.shtml|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}{{cite web|title=2012 World Series Game 4, Giants at Tigers, October 28|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET201210280.shtml|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=October 13, 2017}} ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible autocollapse" style="text-align:center;" |- ! These events would have included the NHL alumni game, as well as outdoor games from all levels, including youth, the [[Ontario Hockey League]], the [[American Hockey League]], and the [[Great Lakes Invitational]]. Due to the [[2012–13 NHL lockout]], the event was cancelled.{{cite web|first=John|last=Vogl|title=Decision day arrives for NHL's Winter Classic|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121101/SPORTS/121109878/1004|website=The Buffalo News|date=November 1, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529131212/http://www.buffalonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121101/SPORTS/121109878/1004|archivedate=May 29, 2016|accessdate=November 9, 2017}}Strang, Katie, and Craig Custance (November 2, 2012). [http://espn.go.com/nhl/story/_/id/8583243/nhl-cancels-winter-classic-toronto-maple-leafs-detroit-red-wings-source-says NHL cancels Winter Classic]. ''ESPN.com''. Retrieved November 2, 2012.National Hockey League. [http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=644824&navid=DL|NHL|home "NHL announces cancellation of 2013 Bridgestone NHL Winter Classic & SiriusXM Hockeytown Winter Festival"], November 2, 2012. Instead, the festival took place in December 2013 where an outdoor rink was set up on the infield of the ballpark for public skating and hockey games.{{cite web|title=Comerica Park Ice Rink Events 19, 2017, Comerica Park hosted its first ever soccer game between [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] of the Italian [[Serie A]] League against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] of France's [[Ligue 1]] in the [[2017 International Champions Cup]] tournament.{{cite web|first=Jared|last=Purcell|title=Paris Saint-Germain tops AS Roma in PKs for 2-1 victory at Comerica Park|url=http://www.mlive.com/sports/detroit/2017/07/live_updates_as_roma_vs_paris.html|website=MLive|date=July 19, 2017|accessdate=November 9, 2017}}{{cite web|first=Brandon|last=Folsom|title=Penalty kicks help Paris Saint-Germain beat AS Roma in Comerica Park soccer match|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/2017/07/20/paris-saint-germain-roma-comerica-park-soccer/494806001/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=July 20, 2017|accessdate=November 9, 2017}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Result !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Losing Team !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Tournament !style="text-align:center; {{Baseball primary style|Detroit Tigers|border=2}};"|Spectators |- |style="text-align:center;"|July 19, 2017||'''{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]'''||style="text-align:center;"|1–1
5-3 ([[Penalty shootout (association football)|pens.]])||{{flagicon|ITA}} [[A.S.
