{{pp|small=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Omid Kordestani
{{-}} ({{lang-fa|امید کردستانی}}) | image = File:Omid Kordestani Web 2.0 conference 2005 (cropped).jpg | caption = Omid Kordestani at the Web 2.0 Conference, 2005 | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1963}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]],[http://www.calstate.edu/BOT/agendas/may08/InstAdv.pdf California] [[Iran]]{{cite web |author=Bob Cooper |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/07/15/CMGLNQPM671.DTL |title=OUT OF IRAN / Five extraordinary Iranian Americans love both countries but loathe their leaders' war talk |publisher=Sfgate.com |date=2007-07-15 |accessdate=2009-12-18}} | citizenship = United States | occupation = [[Chairman#Public corporations|Executive Chairman]], [[Twitter]] | known_for = | net_worth = {{Increase}}[[United States dollar|US$]] 1.9 [[1,000,0000,000 (number)|billion]] (2018){{Cite news|url=https://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/men/omid-kordestani-net-worth/|title=TheRichest - The World's Most Entertaining Site|work=TheRichest|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US}} | spouse = | children = | residence = [[Atherton, California]]{{cite news |title=Unfinished mansion near Google exec sold |url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2010-02-14/real-estate/17876066_1_cb-richard-ellis-google-maps-omid-kordestani |newspaper=SFGate.com |date=February 14, 2010}} | alma_mater = [[San Jose State University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Stanford University]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) | website = | signature = }} '''Omid R. Kordestani''' ({{lang-fa|امید کردستانی}}, born 1963) is an Iranian-Kurdish[https://nypost.com/2015/10/18/the-kurds-could-be-the-key-to-the-middle-east/ '''New York Post''' Omid Kordestani, an ethnic Kurd but now a US citizen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180406164534/https://nypost.com/2015/10/18/the-kurds-could-be-the-key-to-the-middle-east/ |date=2018-04-06}} American businessman who has been the [[Chairman#Public corporations|Executive Chairman]] at [[Twitter]] since October 2015. He was previously a [[Vice president|Senior Vice President]], the [[Chief business officer|Chief Business Officer]], and a special advisor to the CEO and founders at [[Google]] during July 2014 to October 2015{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/corporate/execs.html#omid |title=Management team – Company – Google |accessdate=2015-10-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009035203/https://www.google.com/about/company/facts/management |archivedate=2015-10-09}} and was a director of [[Vodafone]] from March 2013 to October 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.4-traders.com/VODAFONE-GROUP-PLC-4006195/news/Vodafone-Group-plc-Vodafone-Appoints-Omid-Kordestani-as-a-Non-Executive-Director-16369917/ |title=Vodafone Group plc : Vodafone Appoints Omid Kordestani as a Non-Executive Director |publisher=4-traders.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-28}}https://www.linkedin.com/pub/omid-kordestani/51/151/465 Kordestani had also previously been at Google from May 1999 to April 2009, reaching the position of Senior Vice President for Worldwide Sales and Field Operations.{{cite web |last=Hof |first=Rob |url=http://www.businessweek.com/the_thread/techbeat/archives/2009/04/live_google_fir.html |title=LIVE: Google's First-Quarter Earnings: Revenues Down, Profits Beat Forecasts, Investors Yawn |publisher=BusinessWeek |date= |accessdate=2009-12-18}} ==Early life== Omid Kordestani was born in [[Tehran]], Iran to a [[Kurds|Kurdish]] family[http://www.engr.sjsu.edu/alumni/profiles/omid-kordestani Alumni Profiles: Omid Kordestani: Google Inc. Senior Vice President of Global Sales and Business Development] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100625192150/http://www.engr.sjsu.edu/alumni/profiles/omid-kordestani |date=2010-06-25 }}[http://www.calstate.edu/BOT/agendas/may08/InstAdv.pdf Committee on Institutional Advancement: Approval of Meeting Minutes of March 11, 2008]{{cite web |url=http://sfluxe.com/2008/12/27/omid-kordestanis-33-million-year/ |title=San Francisco Luxury Living » Omid Kordestani’s $33 Million Year |publisher=Sfluxe.com |date=2008-12-27 |accessdate=2009-12-18}} and grew up there attending Andisheh Don Bosco School, an Italian Catholic school in Tehran that emphasised education and language skills. He moved to [[San Jose, California]] after the death of his father in 1976.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/magazine/article/OUT-OF-IRAN-Five-extraordinary-Iranian-2581513.php|title=OUT OF IRAN / Five extraordinary Iranian Americans love both countries but loathe their leaders' war talk|work=SFGate|access-date=2018-01-05}} ==Education== Kordestani graduated from [[Buchser High School|Buchser High school]] in 1980. He later received an electrical engineering degree from [[San Jose State University]] and went to work for [[Hewlett Packard]] as an engineer. Several years later in order to pursue a business degree, he entered [[Stanford Business School]] and earned his [[MBA]] in 1991.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/03/12/following-twitters-executive-chairman-and-his-rise-as-an-iranian-immigrant-in-silicon-valley/|title=Following Iranian immigrant Omid Kordestani’s rise in building Google’s business, leading Twitter’s board|date=2017-03-12|work=The Mercury News|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US}} ==Career== Kordestani has more than a dozen years of high-technology consumer and enterprise experience, including key positions at Internet pioneer [[Netscape]] Communications. He was also vice president of Business Development and Sales and grew [[Netscape]]'s website revenue from an annual run-rate of $88 million to more than $200 million in 18 months. He started his career at Netscape as director of OEM Sales, and during his four-year career at that company he was responsible for establishing major customer relationships with [[Citibank]], [[AOL]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], [[Intuit]], [[Travelocity]], [[Intel]], [[@Home Network|@Home]], [[eBay]], and [[Excite]]. Prior to Netscape, Kordestani held positions in marketing, product management, and business development at The 3DO Company, Go Corporation, and Hewlett-Packard. He joined Google in May 1999, leading the development and implementation of the company's initial business model and was Google's senior vice president of worldwide sales and field operations until April 16, 2009. Kordestani played a part in Google's worldwide revenue generation efforts as well as the day-to-day operations of the company’s sales organization. On July 18, 2014, Kordestani came back to Google to fill the vacancy of Chief Business Officer at Google after [[Nikesh Arora]], who was recruited to Google by Kordestani himself, left for [[SoftBank]].{{cite web |url=https://plus.google.com/+LarryPage/posts/XMwh9KieXvT |title=After almost ten years, +Nikesh Arora our Chief Business Officer, has decided… |author=[[Larry Page]] |date=2014-07-18 |accessdate=2015-10-14}}{{cite web |url=https://recode.net/2015/07/20/the-soul-of-google-omid-kordestani-chief-business-officer-returns/ |title=What Omid Kordestani, the Chief Business Officer, Says About Google |publisher=[[Re/code]] |date=2015-07-20 |accessdate=2015-07-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150720181934/http://recode.net/2015/07/20/the-soul-of-google-omid-kordestani-chief-business-officer-returns/ |archivedate=2015-07-20}} Initially interim, his post became permanent in October.{{cite web |url=https://recode.net/2014/10/24/google-ceo-larry-page-reorgs-staff-anoints-sundar-pichai-as-new-product-czar/ |title=Exclusive: Google CEO Larry Page Reorgs Staff, Anoints Sundar Pichai as New Product Czar |publisher=[[Re/code]] |date=2014-10-24 |accessdate=2015-10-14}} On October 14, 2015, Kordestani left Google and became [[Chairman#Public corporations|Executive Chairman]] at [[Twitter]].{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/10/14/twitter-names-googles-omid-kordestani-as-its-new-executive-chairman/ |title=Omid Kordestani Leaves Google, Joins Twitter As Its Executive Chairman |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |date=2015-10-14 |accessdate=2015-10-14}} ==Philanthropy== Kordestani is one of the founders of PARSA Community Foundation, a Persian heritage, entrepreneurship and philanthropic society. ==Personal life== Kordestani is considered one of the wealthiest residents in Northern California. His net worth is estimated to be $1.9 billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/men/omid-kordestani-net-worth/|title=TheRichest - The World's Most Entertaining Site|work=TheRichest|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US}} Kordestani has a son, Milan, who is a competitive [[equestrianism|equestrian]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} ==Recognition== In the May 8, 2006 issue of ''Time Magazine'', Kordestani was named one of Time's "100 People who shape our world".{{cite web |last=Deutsch |first=Donny |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1187475,00.html |title=Omid Kordestani |publisher=TIME |date=2006-04-30 |accessdate=2009-12-18}} Kordestani was selected as the Persian Person of the Year in 2007 by Persian Awards despite not being ethnicically Persian.{{cite web |url=http://www.payvand.com/news/08/dec/1202.html |title=In The Spotlight: International Awards and the Accomplished Iranians Who Have Earned Them |publisher=Payvand.com |date=2006-11-22 |accessdate=2009-12-18}} ==See also== * [[List of Iranian Americans]] *[[Pierre Omidyar]] *[[Parisa Tabriz]] *[[Roozbeh Pournader]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.google.com/corporate/execs.html#omid Official page on Google] * [http://www.time.com/time/globalbusiness/article/0,9171,1101030728-466027,00.html Article on Time magazine about Omid Kordestani] {{Twitter Navigation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kordestani, Omid}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Lead too short|date=September 2016}} '''Opposition to [[Trade union|trade unions]]''' comes from a variety of groups in society and there are many different types of argument on which this opposition is based. ==Economic effects== ===Unemployment=== The economist [[Milton Friedman]], advocate of [[laissez-faire]] capitalism, believed that unionization frequently produces higher wages at the expense of fewer jobs, and that, if some industries are unionized while others are not, wages will decline in non-unionized industries.Milton & Rose Friedman, ''[[Free to Choose]]''. Chicago Press, 1979 By raising the price of labor, the [[wage rate]], above the [[equilibrium price]], unemployment rises. This is because it is no longer worthwhile for businesses to employ those laborers whose work is worth less than the minimum wage rate set by the unions.Alain Anderton, ''Economics'', Fourth edition Trade unions often benefit ''insider'' workers, those having a secure job and high productivity, at the cost of ''outsider'' workers, consumers of the goods or services produced, and the shareholders of the unionized business. The ones who are likely to lose the most from a trade union are those who are unemployed or at the risk of unemployment or who are not able to get the job that they want in a particular field.''Economics'', 16th edition, Samuelson Nordhaus{{page needed|date=July 2013}} ===Harm to ununionized labor=== Advocates of unions claim that the higher wages that unions demand can be paid for through company profits.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} However, as Milton Friedman pointed out, profits are only very rarely high enough. 80% of national income is wages, and only about 6% is profits after tax, providing very little room for higher wages, even if profits could be totally used up. Moreover, profits are invested leading to an increase in capital: which raises the value of labor, increasing wages. If profits were totally removed, this source of wage increase would be removed.Milton & Rose Friedman, ''Free to Choose'', 1979 According to The New York Times, wages in 2012 fell to a record low of 43.5 percent of [[Gross domestic product|GDP]]. ===Efficiency=== [[Friedrich Hayek]] argued that the effect of union activities to influence pricing is potentially very harmful, making the market system ineffective.F. A. Hayek, ''The Constitution of Liberty'', 1960 Routledge Classics{{page needed|date=July 2013}} ===Cost-push inflation=== By causing wage increases above the market rate, unions increase the cost to businesses, causing them to raise their prices, leading to a [[inflation|general increase in the price level]]. [[Austrian School|Austrian economists]] such as [[Robert P. Murphy]], however, dispute this, arguing that the increase in the cost of labor simply means that less of other goods can be bought. He writes:
If unions succeed in wage hikes, and employers raise the prices they charge consumers to maintain their own profit margins, and the supply of money remains the same, then something else has to "give." Either the prices of goods and services in nonunion sectors have to fall and offset the union sector hikes, or people's cash balances need to fall, in terms of their purchasing power.{{cite web |author=Robert P. Murphy |url=http://www.mises.org/story/2839 |title=Can Unions Cause Price Inflation? |publisher=[[Mises Institute]] |accessdate=18 October 2011}}
===Corruption=== Some trade unions, such as the [[Teamsters#Influence of organized crime|Teamsters]], have been criticized for involvement with [[organized crime]].{{cite book |last=Fitch|first=Robert|title=Solidarity for Sale: How Corruption Destroyed the Labor Movement and Undermined American Promise|year=2006|publisher=PublicAffairs|pages=134–55}} ===General response to economic arguments=== The argument that unionized workers raise their own wages above their natural rate at the expense of their businesses or other workers assumes that unions never raise productivity to compensate for higher wages. Unions are capable of raising productivity by reducing turnover, by increasing coordination between workers and management, and by increasing workers' motivation.http://cep.lse.ac.uk/people/vanreenen/lecture_notes/handbook_metcalf.pdf{{cite web |url=http://www.aflcio.org/joinaunion/why/uniondifference/uniondiff8.cfm |title=Unions Are Good for Business, Productivity and the Economy |publisher=Aflcio.org |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211064646/http://www.aflcio.org/joinaunion/why/uniondifference/uniondiff8.cfm |archivedate=11 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1153/is_v108/ai_3579390/ |title=Union productivity effects | Monthly Labor Review |publisher=Find Articles |accessdate=18 October 2011 |year=1985 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107232744/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1153/is_v108/ai_3579390/ |archivedate= 7 January 2012 |df= }} Many unions raise the productivity of their workers, and some even raise it enough to make up for wage increases. Another argument raised by union supporters is that unionized workers will spend their higher wages, driving economic growth and creating new jobs.http://www.americanprogressaction.org/issues/2009/02/efca_factsheets.html Union opponents respond that this is an example of the [[broken window fallacy]]; union supporters assume that money is more valuable in the hands of unionized workers than in the hands of whoever else would obtain it in the union's absence. There is some evidence that this is not a fallacy, as greater [[wealth equality]] seems to be correlated with greater economic growth.Andrew Berg and Jonathan D. Ostry, 2011, "[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/sdn/2011/sdn1108.pdf Inequality and Unsustainable Growth: Two Sides of the Same Coin]?" IMF Staff Discussion Note SDN/11/08, [[International Monetary Fund]] Union supporters counter that unions, if organized without violence or government help, are part of the free market; if unions can win higher wages for their workers without coercion, those wages are legitimate.http://c4ss.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/C4SS-Labor.pdf ===Social disruption=== [[Trade unions]] take strike actions that result in the disruption of public serviceshttp://journals.sfu.ca/archivar/index.php/archivaria/article/viewFile/10489/11328{{cite web |url=http://www.indiatogether.org/combatlaw/vol2/issue6/strike.htm |title=Critique of SC's ruling on the right to strike, from Volume 2, Issue 6, of Combat Law |publisher=Indiatogether.org |accessdate=18 October 2011}} – as demonstrated in the British [[Winter of Discontent]].{{cite journal |title=Chronicles of a Death Foretold: the Winter of Discontent and Construction of the Crisis of British Keynesianism |author=Colin Hay |journal=Parliamentary Affairs |year=2010 |volume=63 |pages=446–70 |doi=10.1093/pa/gsp056 |issue=3}} However, where applicable, this may be logically inferred to be the very purpose of strike action ''per se''.{{cite web |url=http://hawaiifreepress.com/main/ArticlesMain/tabid/56/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/1360/Furlough-negotiations-50M-ransom-offered-but-unions-balk-at-releasing-hostages.aspx |title=Furlough negotiations: $50M ransom offered, but unions balk at releasing hostages |publisher=Hawaii Free Press |accessdate=18 October 2011}}{{cite news | url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/letters/unions-will-hold-us-all-to-ransom-1820400.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Unions will hold us all to ransom | date=14 July 2009}} In some cases, unions' strike have led to violent clashes with police and with strikebreakers. See the article on the [[UK miners' strike (1984–1985)#Violence|UK miners' strike of the 1980s]]. ==Challenges from affirmative action perspectives== ===Racist policies in the past=== A consequence of unions' zeal to guard their special interests is that some unions have actively lobbied for racist and anti-immigration policies. An example is the creation of the notorious [[Asiatic Exclusion League]], which was composed mainly of the various labor unions. The ''Pictorial History of American Labor'' observes,
The early A.F. of L. did not draw the color line, but expressed an "ideal of solidarity irrespective of race." Before long, however, the feeling changed. Whether a tendency to exclude black workers from craft unions was based more on fear of competition or racial prejudice carried over from slave days, it is difficult to decide. But the developing exclusion of the Negro worker from many neighbor unions brought with it serious problems—not just for the black worker seeking job security, but for the white worker seeking the same end...
The record shows that black workers...have been used to break strikes. This availability has usually ended when the black worker has been shown that the union is open to black as well as white.''A Pictorial History of American Labor'', William Cahn, 1972, p. 160.
However, in a study called ''The Black Worker'', Spero and Harris observe that more strikes [in American labor history] have been broken by white workers than by black workers. Most blacks were barred from membership in the AFL not because of their skin color, but because they never had a chance to learn a skill, and "most A.F. of L. unions did not admit unskilled mass-production workers."''A Pictorial History of American Labor'', William Cahn, 1972, p. 231. While the [[AFL-CIO]] is the modern version of the AFL, it is much more open to membership by women, immigrants, and different nationalities. Other unions, such as the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] and the [[International Longshore and Warehouse Union]], were created without regard to race from the very start.''Solidarity Forever – An oral history of the IWW'', Stewart Bird, Dan Georgakas, Deborah Shaffer, 1985, p. 140. == Government == [[File:Illegal Union Firing 1952 - 2007.svg|thumb|280px|Illegal union firing increased during the [[Reagan administration]] and has continued since.[http://www.businessweek.com/archives/1994/b337360.arc.htm "Why America Needs Unions"], ''BusinessWeek'']] Specific countries, especially undemocratic countries, while still having unions in ''name'', do not allow for independent trade unions, just as they rarely allow for independent businesses. These state-run trade unions do not function in the same way as independent trade unions and generally do not hold any kind of collective bargaining power, acting to ensure the smooth running of Government industry.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} Attempts to reduce the effects of trade unions may include [[union busting]] activities by private [[company|companies]] or state action including governments of authoritarian regimes such as in [[Adolf Hitler]]'s Nazi Germany{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/fight/sfeature/sf_nazis_02.html |title=American Experience | The Fight | Nazis in the News |publisher=PBS |accessdate=18 October 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.colby.edu/personal/r/rmscheck/GermanyE1.html |title=E: The Third Reich |publisher=Colby.edu |accessdate=18 October 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://pmaci.customer.netspace.net.au/ncop.htm |title=The Creation Of A Fascist Dictatorship / Totalitarian State In Germany |publisher=Pmaci.customer.netspace.net.au |date=27 February 1933 |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004121038/http://pmaci.customer.netspace.net.au/ncop.htm |archivedate=4 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and Burma's military dictator, [[Ne Win]]. Many democratic governments have also attempted to limit the effects of unions, although success has been mixed. It has been argued, particularly by market anarchists, that government intervention in the economy has been decidedly anti-union, even in economies like the United States or the European Union. [[Kevin Carson]] maintains that the most effective union tactics are either criminalized or displaced by state policy in most countries. Trade unions established themselves through [[sitdown strike]]s, [[sympathy strikes]], [[secondary boycotts]], and hot cargo agreements; these tactics are all illegal in most industrialized countries. Similarly, the original unions doubled as social welfare organization, using union funds to provide healthcare and pensions to workers and welfare to the unemployed. By adopting various welfare-state measures, governments made the populace less dependent on unions. ==Left critiques of trade unionism== [[File:Anti-union ASF flyer.jpg|thumb|An [[anarcho-syndicalism|anarcho-syndicalist]] flyer exhorting workers to "Give Union Bosses the Flick!"]] The political left is often associated with support for trade unionism. However, some groups and individuals have taken a less positive view. In the nineteenth century, a belief in the [[iron law of wages]] led some socialists to reject trade unionism and strike action as ineffective. In this view, any increase in wages would lead manufacturers to raise ''prices'' leaving workers no better off in real terms. [[Karl Marx]] wrote a pamphlet, "[[Wages, Price and Profit]]", to counter this idea, which had been put forward in the [[International Workingmen's Association]] by a follower of [[Robert Owen]]. Some early [[social democracy|Social Democrats]] were also skeptical of trade unionism. Usual criticisms were that unions split workers into sections rather than organising them as a class; that they were dominated by relatively privileged skilled workers who were mainly concerned to defend their sectional interests; and that industrial action and organisation were incapable of bringing about fundamental social change. [[H. M. Hyndman]] of the [[Social Democratic Federation]] summed up some of these views when he wrote in ''The Historical Basis of Socialism in England'' (1883): :"Trade Unions ... constitute an aristocracy of labour who [are] ... a hindrance to that complete organisation of the proletariat which alone can obtain for the workers their proper control over their own labour ... Being also ... unsectarian and unpolitical, they prevent any organised attempt being made by the workers as a class to form a definite party of their own, apart from existing factions, with a view to dominate the social conditions – a victory which ... can only be gained by resolute political action." Hyndman went on to urge workers to devote "the Trade Union funds wasted on strikes or petty funds" instead to the building up of a strong Socialist Party on the German model. Other social democrats however were more convinced than Hyndman of the utility of Trade Union action. Trade unionism is criticised by those of [[council communism|council communist]] and [[left communism|left communist]] tendencies."Unions Against the Working Class", International Communist Current http://en.internationalism.org/pamphlets/unions.htm Here, trade unionism is seen as being more useful to capitalists than to workers, and as a kind of "safety-valve" that helps to keep working-class discontent within reformist channels and prevent it from evolving into revolutionary action. They consider a global state composed of [[workers' council]]s to be the ultimate union to which all workers in the world belong; unions that organize based on trade further divide the working class and act as a mechanism to allow the working class to vent concerns without actually uniting and becoming revolutionary. In contrast to other left critiques of trade unionism, these tendencies do not accept that the problems they identify could be remedied by changing the structure, leadership or objectives of trade unions. They argue that trade unionism is inherently reformist because it is sectarian and is not founded in the workplace itself and that revolutionary action is possible only if workers act outside trade unionism through [[soviet (council)|workers' councils]] or other channels. There is also a philosophical difference between the [[craft unionism]] of many AFL-type unions, and the [[industrial unionism]] of organizations such as the Industrial Workers of the World. Industrial unionists decry a practice that they call "union scabbing," in which craft unionists are required by the no-strike clause in their contracts to cross the picket lines of other unions.''Roughneck: The Life and Times of Big Bill Haywood''. Peter Carlson, 1983, p. 80. There is also the left critique of the tendencies of some labor unions to become [[bureaucracy|bureaucratic]] and for the union leaders and staff to become detached from the needs and interests of the [[wikt:rank and file|rank and file]] union members, in contrast to the practices of [[union democracy]]. The [[Labor Notes (organization)|Labor Notes]], in the United States, is an example of an organization that attempts to fight this bureaucratic tendency. == See also == {{Portal|Organized labour}} '''Violence:''' * [[Union violence]] * [[Anti-union violence]] * [[United States v. Enmons]] * [[Freedom from Union Violence Act]] * [[Wagner Act]] ==References== *[[Joseph Stiglitz]] (2002). [https://web.archive.org/web/20060725114900/http://www2.gsb.columbia.edu/faculty/jstiglitz/download/2002_Emploi_justice_sociale.pdf ''Employment, social justice and societal well-being''] International Labour Review, 141 (1–2), p. 9 – 29. *Business Standard (2014). [http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ani/international-trade-unions-need-to-be-less-combative-encourage-more-interaction-with-workers-114122600503_1.html International trade unions need to be less combative,encourage more interaction with workers] ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[https://mises.org/library/union-myth The free market - the union myth] Thomas J. DiLorenzo The Free Market 24, no. 10 (October 2004) Mises Institute {{Organized labor}} [[Category:Labor relations]] [[Category:Trade unions]] [[Category:Criticism of trade unions]]

{{infobox military award | name = Order of Aeronautical Merit | image = | caption = | awarded_by = [[Brazilian Air Force]] | country = {{BRA}} | type = [[Order (honour)|State Order]] | eligibility = | for = Distinguished service and exceptional contributions to the Brazilian Air Force. | campaign = | status = | description = | motto = | clasps = | post-nominals = | established = 1 November 1943 | first_award = | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = | same = | lower = | related = | image2 = | caption2 = }} The '''Order of Aeronautical Merit''' ({{lang-pt|Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico}}) is an award of the [[Brazilian Air Force]], established on 1 November 1943 by [[President of Brazil|President]] [[Getúlio Vargas]]. The order is presented in five grades and recognizes distinguished service and exceptional contributions to the Brazilian Air Force.<ref name="MoW">{{cite web | last =Robertson | first =Megan C. | title =The Federative Republic of Brazil: Order of Aeronautical Merit | work =Medals of the World | publisher = | date =14 July 2007 | url =http://www.medals.org.uk/brazil/fr-brazil/fr-brazil006.htm | format = | doi = | accessdate =2011-09-20}}</ref>
==Grades== The order is awarded in the following grades:<ref>{{cite web|title=DECRETO No 3.446, DE 4 DE MAIO DE 2000. Aprova o Regulamento da Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico e dá outras providências.|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto/D3446.htm|website=Palácio do Planalto|publisher=Presidência da República Casa Civil Subchefia para Assuntos Jurídicos|accessdate=17 January 2015|language=Portuguese}}</ref> * [[File:BRA Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico Grã-Cruz.png|105px]] Grand Cross (''Grã-Cruz'') * [[File:BRA Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico Grande Oficial.png|105px]] Grand Officer (''Grande Oficial'') * [[File:BRA Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico Comendador.png|105px]] Commander (''Comendador'') * [[File:BRA Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico Oficial.png|105px]] Officer (''Oficial'') * [[File:BRA Ordem do Mérito Aeronáutico Cavaleiro.png|105px]] Knight (''Cavaleiro'')
==Notable recipients== * [[Stéphane Abrial]], French * [[Henri Sauvan]], French * [[Ira C. Eaker]], American * [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], American, ''Grand Cross'' (August 5, 1946)<ref>{{cite web|title=USA and Foreign Decorations of Dwight D Eisenhower|url=https://www.eisenhower.archives.gov/all_about_ike/awards_medals.html|work=Dwight D Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum|publisher=National Archives and Records Administration (United States Government)|accessdate=6 December 2012|quote=Brazil: Order of Aeronautical Merit, Grand Cross (August 5, 1946)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118062616/https://eisenhower.archives.gov/all_about_ike/awards_medals.html|archivedate=18 November 2016|df=}}</ref> * [[Leonard T. Gerow]], American * [[Bruce K. Holloway]], American * [[Jonas H. Ingram]], American * [[Jacques Paul Klein]], American * [[Curtis LeMay]], American * [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]], Brazilian * [[Donald A. Quarles]], American * [[John Dale Ryan]], American * [[Michael E. Ryan]], American
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Usce is not the tallest building even in Belgrade (West Gate/Zapadna Kapija is 115m tall, 135m with antenna, 35 floors)
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Petar Matić | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|09|03|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Maribor]], [[SR Slovenia]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] | residence = | nationality = Serbian | alma_mater = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | net_worth = | spouse = | website = }} '''Petar Matić''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Петар Матић}}; born on 3 September 1966) is a Serbian [[businessman]] and the owner of [[MPC Holding]] and MPC Properties. He is believed to be one of the richest people in Serbia.<ref>[http://www.blic.rs/Vesti/Drustvo/235460/300-najmocnijih-u-Srbiji 300 Most influential people in Serbia] (Serbian)</ref>
==Biography== Matić was born in Maribor, Slovenia and studied at the Faculty of Hotel Management in Opatija, [[Croatia]]. Before moving to [[Belgrade]], Serbia, he had already developed a business on the Croatian coast mainly involved in retail footwear and apparel.
After moving to Belgrade in 1989 Matić founded the company MPC (incorporating his initials into the name), which went on to be very successful in the following years. In 1991 MPC was transformed into the MPC Group with significant growth and expanded activities. In 2003 it had two main divisions: Real Estate and [[Trade]].
Soon afterwards, Matić went on to establish MPC Holding and MPC Properties, a leading companies in trade and real estate development in the region. In 2007 MPC Properties entered into the strategic partnership with [[Merrill Lynch]] / [[Bank of America]]. This was the first investment made by Merill Lynch in the territory of former Yugoslavia.<ref>[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/business-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=01&dd=08&nav_id=46768 Merrill Lynch co-owns MPC Properties]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Matić's companies are now market leaders in that part of Europe.<ref>[http://www.ekapija.com/website/sr/page/213011_en "Balkans Real Estate" to invest 1 billion EUR in real estates in Serbia and in region within next five years]</ref> They currently employ over 1,000 people and are some of the most significant investors in Serbia. The companies have been awarded retail, commercial, residential and logistics projects that are of immense importance in the region for example the [[Ušće Tower|Business Center Ušće]]<ref>[http://filipovic-advisory.com/UserFiles/File/cren/cren-broj-35-eng.pdf MPC Opens the Largest Shopping Centre in the Region]</ref>, the Usce Shopping Center (the first regional shopping mall), IMMO outlet Centers, Business Center “Tri Lista Duvana” and residential/condominium “OASIS”.
Matić chooses to stay out of the public eye, as he does not give interviews to the press, and his photographs cannot be found in local [[newspapers]].<ref>[http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Ekonomija/Nevidljivi-vlasnik-Ushca.lt.html Invisible Usce owner] (Serbian)</ref>
Matić is also a member of ICSC - International Council of Shopping Centres.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Matic, Petar}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Slovenian people of Serbian descent]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Maribor]]
